id: Artistic technique, comaparing ai art with regular art
comments: this looks great if it were my drawing i would just jump into rendering at this point i would also look at some underwater references to see how certain colors and tons are when looking through an amount of water i imagine colors will be kinda less saturated when looking through water also maybe some beams of light refracting from the surface in the background
thank you the shine and transparency is so much fun to recreate

anatomy will take longer to master whereas other fundamentals you will see competency in a few years it is helpful to browse though art instructional books at your library this is what artists did before the internet they are detailed enough to give principles along with reasoning

they seem to have a 3d shape in blender and i also converted one into an stlfile which can be 3d printed maybe just needed to use solidify in blender not very good 3d model though so i havent tried to print it picture is from cura

all images except the 5th one have some weirdness to it something funky that doesnt make sense like tje forehead shading on the merged jawgear thing on the weird hand on and the spikes on the head being sorta random on id also say that theres a smoothness too all the ai art too but i dont know how to explain that if some part of the piece looks off is merging with something else or looks unnaturally smooth it might be ai though its really hard to tell sometimes

i have a short attention span so i do body paint murals and paint on demand projects that move quickly and i can not linger on them i am impatient so i dont use oils or anything with a long drying time i chafe under structure so i dont do illustrations or ink based work i love color and blending so i use airbrush which is great at that i work better under pressureso i work in front of audiences so i can not procrastinate or walk away when you are posed with a challenge in any facet of life or in art you have to decide to take it on or walk away if you take it on and succeed great if you fail you have a few choices walk away flight try again repeat break the barrier fight or go around invent thats really all there is to it your personality will determine how you take on these obstacles you can be coached or follow someones example but in the end it is your decision to make to be more specific someone would need to know your life history your motivation and what is in your vision this is all impossible so you can rage at how vague the advice seems but people are basically being as honest as they can be the rest is up to you let me repeat that and try to really meditate on this it is not an easy thought to master actually you are the captain of your own destiny you are responsible and to you goes the credit but this thing i know if you cant figure this part outdont be an artist get a safe career in a safe field with people who do safe things the field of art is no place for those who will not fight invent repeat and take a beating now and then it is not easy but the rewards are wonderful for those who figure it out

honestly im still struggling to grasp how you managed to get the reflection over the transparency of the water to look like this its just so convincing and yet still somehow retains the looseness of watercolor absolutely phenomenal
what you need is for mj to create the stencil
ai always tries to do too much like in the picture on the right vs the regular looking left

some pieces are stronger than others with the second one being my favorite and a the first one my second fave you tend to have nice color selections and seem to be having a nice time and youre probably still figuring out what you do and dont like or do and dont want in a painting i see youve sort of experimented with texture and pattern and stuff too thats awesome i think its great that youve started and if you like it definitely keep going

fursona request this is the my first go at coloring digitally using clip studio paint i think the usual critiques would be helpful proportions line work etc i went simple with the color this time around

i feel like theres definetly some potential here if it was me the first thing id do is lose the secondary font in serif for the tagline the serif does not go well with the primary font and is also probably not a good fit for a modern tech industry that i believe the company is going to work in also i understand the client wanted their original logomark to reimain the same but it is a little too generic i believe could look into altering it using part of it or some other method to make it look more like a logomark and less like an iconclipart one suggestion since i see the services mentioned latermapping photography etc revolve around using a drone camera to accomplish them id probably try to combine a camera and a drone or something like that in page i like the drone logomark laid over the intitals hs id try making something interesting like a pattern out of that maybe in page i dont like the option at the top it is very rare that you see a logomark to the left of the name of your company the most distinguishing piece of a companys brand is its logomark and ideally that should be the first thing people see so having it at the left is the best choice since people read left to right congratulations on getting your first project i hope you have fun wishing you all the best edit grammar edit forgot to add id also maybe like to see a brief that you used to come up with some of the design decisions

even though it looks like a simple painting theres a lot of technical work that you need to gave a grasp of eg colour theory tones perspective detail work etc the tones and colour in the reference are more realistic and far closer together than you would imagine training your eyes to see slight variations in colour saturation hue is something that takes work it also looks like the reference is painted on watercolour paper with gouache paint which is an entirely different ball game to working with acrylic but gives that lovely matt finish dont beat yourself up as you said youre only a beginner id recommend watching some tutorials on the fundamentals of paintingart and doing lots of practise and youll get the hang of it and i also dont think your painting is bad theres definitely a lot of potential

lol thanks its not like theres just one way to do it so probably just try a bunch of stuff and see what gives you results that you like for me drawing is about taking a 3d thing and rendering it in 2d but in a way that tricks people into thinking the 2d version is showing 3d sort of like taking a piece of writing in english and then translating it into japanese and then back into english there are editorial and technical considerations and no two translators are going to approach the work with the same exact ideas

that makes sense the purpose of therapy isnt just for you to go in and take an emotional dump once a week it also exists to provide you a model of a healthy close relationship the one between you and the therapist so you can practice whatever relational skills you have a deficit in with them in a judgmentfree safe space and then take that into your real relationships if a therapist is bad for you you wont be able to click enough for that to take place

do you say that because its digital art i drew it with a wacom intuos pro and clip studio paint while i utilized some proprietary brushes for the background the two characters i drew the same as if i was using pen and markers
or covered up by construction paper for our safety

i can also attest to the princeton neptune brushes my current scores are the holbein liquid sizing which i havent gotten to play with much but im curious to see how it will work re keeping the paper wet longer and blending i have a very small space and no room for a big boi flat pallet so these nesting porcelain bowls have saved my hide so much the one that kills me is i got some microfiber cleaning clothes from homehome a korean sort of bed bath and beyondand then they closed to the pandemic and i no longer have the packaging they are the best they are very soft and leave very little to no texture when dabbing up wet washes

late to the post but you sherman copic markers theyre high end professional rendering markers that behave similarly to watercolor paint but theres no clean up making super accessible theyre expensive but refillable and that will teach her to value her materials i would advise getting her a marker paper sketchbook as well different papers accept materials differently
the girl in the second one looks like she is from whoville with the little nose looks great though what ai did you use

the works of arthur schopenhauer a german philosopher who was a significant influence on nietzsche also dealt with the cyclical nature of ideas schopenhauer posited that human desires and suffering were driven by a metaphysical force he called the will which perpetually seeks satisfaction but is never fully satiated in this framework the cyclical nature of ideas emerges from the restless striving of the will and the human drive to find meaning in existence the philosopher søren kierkegaard often considered the father of existentialism also touched upon the cyclical nature of ideas he emphasized the importance of individual choice and personal responsibility in shaping ones existence and in doing so he highlighted the constant struggle between opposing forces within human nature kierkegaard believed that this struggle leads to a repetitive cycle of selfdiscovery and selfdoubt as individuals constantly reevaluate their beliefs and values moving into the 20th century the cyclical nature of ideas continued to be explored by philosophers and thinkers oswald spengler a german historian and philosopher developed the idea of the morphological similarity of historical cycles he argued that the development of human societies and cultures followed a cyclical pattern with distinct stages of growth maturity decline and eventual collapse spenglers ideas emphasized the cyclical nature of human history and the recurrence of similar patterns across different civilizations in the realm of psychology carl gustav jung developed the concept of archetypes universal recurring symbols or patterns found throughout human history and culture these archetypes according to jung are part of the collective unconscious a deep layer of the human psyche that transcends individual experience the cyclical nature of ideas in jungs view is tied to the recurrence of these archetypes as they continuously manifest in new forms across time and space the french philosopher and anthropologist claude lévistrauss also explored the cyclical nature of ideas through his structuralist approach to studying human societies he posited that cultural phenomena such as myths and rituals are organized around binary oppositions which reveal deepseated structures in the human mind these oppositions according to lévistrauss give rise to recurring patterns and cycles in human thought and behavior in the field of sociology the concept of the cyclical nature of ideas can be found in the work of pitirim sorokin sorokins theory of social and cultural dynamics argued that societies oscillate between periods of ideational idealistic and sensate culture these cycles he believed are driven by the interplay of social economic and political factors as well as by the internal dynamics of human thought and behavior the postmodern philosopher jeanfrançois lyotard also dealt with the cyclical nature of ideas in his critique of grand narratives or metanarratives the overarching unifying stories that societies tell themselves lyotard argued that these metanarratives are constantly being challenged and deconstructed leading to a cyclical process of meaningmaking abstract texttoimage model personalization aims to introduce a userprovided concept to the model allowing its synthesis in diverse contexts however current methods primarily focus on the case of learning a single concept from multiple images with variations in backgrounds and poses and struggle when adapted to a different scenario in this work we introduce the task of textual scene decomposition given a single image of a scene that may contain several concepts we aim to extract a distinct text token for each concept enabling finegrained control over the generated scenes to this end we propose augmenting the input image with masks that indicate the presence of target concepts these masks can be provided by the user or generated automatically by a pretrained segmentation model we then present a novel twophase customization process that optimizes a set of dedicated textual embeddings handles as well as the model weights striking a delicate balance between accurately capturing the concepts and avoiding overfitting we employ a masked diffusion loss to enable handles to generate their assigned concepts complemented by a novel loss on crossattention maps to prevent entanglement we also introduce unionsampling a training strategy aimed to improve the ability of combining multiple concepts in generated images we use several automatic metrics to quantitatively compare our method against several baselines and further affirm the results using a user study finally we showcase several applications of our method

all versions of the cloudy lightroom called just lightroom lightroom cc doesnt exist anymore it is now just and very confusingly lightroom are basically the same whether you run them on ipad iphone android or on a desktop computer the tools are sometimes in different locations but the apps all have all the masking tools healing color grading etc it might just be harder to find on a tiny phone screen the only thing missing from the mobile versions is enhance details panorama merging and hdr merging apart from that the mobile versions are identical to the desktop version lightroom classic is a completely different beast but does have identical processing tools to lightroom ie the cloudbased version running on desktop computers including the enhance details hdr and panorama merging classic also has many more file organization features can do soft proofing can print ie is what most people probably should use however adobe heavily markets the less full featured cloudbased version only great feature of it is that all your images are in the cloud and are identical wherever you run lightroom

in lightroom nonclassic preferences the local storage is set as user pictures lightroom library and its about 6gb in size the corresponding storage folder found on lr nonclassic contains a file lightroom librarylrlibrary that is 67gb lightroom librarylrlibrary is the sort of catalog that lr cloud desktop uses it stores in its subfolders the data about the cloud photos their previews and some of the full res files the full res files download if they are not locally available whenever they are needed if you delete lightroom librarylrlibrary lr will recreate it from scratch the next time you launch it and will start downloading again the previews and some full res files from the cloud as far as lr cloud is concerned the main storage of the photos is the cloud what you have on your devices are just local copies of your cloud photos you can set in lr preferences some minimal limits so that this locally saved cloud storage doesnt take much space all this has nothing to do with lrc which appears that is setup correctly

ive built a handmade camera or two my best was a scanner camera with a schneider 180mm lens a 4x6 inch sensor area and a fresnel to collimate the light cone from the schneider is your fresnel just for focusing on the ground glass or is it part of the camera and gon na be there when youre taking a picture i dont think you would need the later for film if its part of the taking process my best piece of advice is to space the fresnel away from the film so you dont get the fresnel pattern on film on my camera i had a little over one cm of space between the fresnel and the surface of the scanner second piece would be to match the fresnels focal length to the lenses focal length have it be as close to 90mm as you can get a hold of

digital was designed to imitate film as far as exposure exposure is nothing but combination of scene luminance exposure time and fnumber there is no imitation there in either case it is the measure of how sensative the film or sensor is to light no it is not iso number has absolutely nothing to do with image sensor sensitivity the iso standad defines iso as a property of output format eg jpg not raw data nor anytning with sensor sensitivity changing the iso setting changes cameras metering target exposure it changes the lightness of the jpg if you shoot jpgs and typically image sensor operational parameters are also changed in digital it is an analog sensor pixel is indeed an analogue device and an amplifier to give the effect of iso no it doesnt the effect of iso is a matter of processing at least according to the iso standard btw there are two amplification stages in cmos image sensors first in the pixel itself and then in the programmable gain amplifier in either case if you have a iso film or a digital camera set to iso if you set aperture and shutter speed the same you will get the same exposure the iso is irrelevant if the scene luminance fnumber and exposure times are the same then the exposure is the same how light the result will be depends entirely on processing either cameras jpg engines or what one does with the rawprocessor
